title: Overview of bone health topics to be discussed
content: Peter provides an overview of bone mineral density, how it’s measured, how it changes over the course of life, and the variability between sexes largely due to changes in estrogen levels. Additionally, he discusses what happens when one may be forced to be sedentary (e.g., bedrest) and how you can work to minimize the damage during these periods.

title: Types of physical activity that can positively impact bone health
content: Peter discusses types of physical activity that can positively impact bone health.

title: Nutrition and supplements for bone health
content: Peter discusses nutrition and supplements for bone health.

title: Pharmaceutical drugs prescribed for those with low BMD
content: Peter discusses pharmaceutical drugs prescribed for those with low BMD.

title: Overview of bone health topics to be discussed
content: Today’s episode is all things bone health: bone mineral density, osteopenia, osteoporosis, things of that nature. We’ll talk about how bone health changes as people age, the differences between sexes in men and women. Then we’ll also focus on things on how people can improve or help their bone health become better from physical activity to nutrition, supplements, drugs, and more.

title: Bones 101: bone function, structure, and more
content: Bone is a living tissue. It’s easy to forget this fact and think of bone as somewhat inert. But bone is heavily vascularized. Bone is an organ that plays a very important role in a lot of things. Cortical/compact bone is what forms the “shaft” and the exterior of long bones. You also have the trabecular bone/spongy bone.

title: Bone Marrow
content: Marrow is important because it is what’s producing our white cells and our red blood cells. In a post COVID world, it’s important to understand that the memory B cells and memory T-cells that are going to provide lasting immunity against this virus and other viruses, reside in the bone marrow. The whole purpose of being infected and then having a subsequent infection that’s less devastating, (and purpose of being vaccinated) for the same reason is to have memory B cells and T-cells that are sitting there in the bone marrow that can respond immediately and quickly upon reintroduction of the same antigen.

title: Osteoblasts and Osteoclasts
content: Osteoblasts are responsible for building bone by producing collagen bone matrix and mineralizing it. Osteoclasts remove bone by reabsorbing calcified bone and the matrix. So osteoblasts contribute to increasing bone mineral density. Osteoclasts the opposite. This exists in an equilibrium—We’re constantly remodeling bone, adding to and subtracting from this and basically turning over calcium.

title: Bone Minerals
content: Bone is 50 to 70% mineral. It’s about 20 to 40% organic matrix. Then the rest of it is a bit of water and lipid. In an adult, the entire human skeletal system can be remodeled in a really long cycle. It might take 10 years to turn over all of the mineral and organic content within the bone over and over again. At the micro level, calcium balance is happening quite frequently. Virtually all of the body’s calcium is contained within bone and therefore bone plays a very important role in calcium homeostasis. Calcium signaling is important to everything within a cell.

title: Vitamin D and Bones
content: There’s two forms of vitamin D, vitamin D2 and D3. D3 is the active form. Vitamin D increases the gut’s absorption of calcium. If you’re woefully deficient in vitamin D, you’re going to have trouble absorbing calcium through the gut. The other thing that you can’t avoid here is understanding the role of calcium and parathyroid hormone. Most people are probably familiar with their thyroid gland—sits in the neck and it’s got two main lobes and then each lobe has two poles. At each of those poles is a little tiny gland called the parathyroid gland (so you have four of those glands). And the parathyroid gland is really the master gland for regulating calcium levels.

title: Consequences of Poor Bone Health
content: Five years ago, Peter was not paying nearly as much attention to bone health as he is today.

title: Accidental Deaths by Category
content: Accidental deaths are broken down into four categories: Overdoses, Transportation accidents (car accidents), Falls, and Everything else. Those first three represent virtually all accidental deaths.

title: Predominant Causes of Accidental Death by Age
content: For people younger than 60, overdoses are the predominant cause of accidental death. For people over 65, falling is the primary cause.

title: Risk of Death from Falling
content: By the time you’re 75, the risk of death from a fall is enormous. It’s not as high as Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, or heart disease, but it comes in pretty much just after that.

title: Excess Mortality Following a Hip Fracture
content: Figure 3 shows excess mortality following a hip fracture for women and men. If you’re a man that is 90 years old or above and you have a hip fracture, more than 40% of you will be dead within a year. If you’re 70 years old and you break your hip, only 10% of those people are going to be dead in three years, but that number just keeps going up and up and up. For people over the age of 80, your mortality is in the neighborhood of a third within a year after a hip fracture.

title: High Mortalities in Other Fractions
content: In a study of 200 people who were 65 or older who fractured their hip, the mortality was 25%. Michael Easter's book, The Comfort Crisis, references some of these studies.

title: Hip Fractures and Mortality
content: Studies have shown that mortality rates for patients over 50 years old with hip fractures range from just under 14% to over 27%. The hazard ratio for mortality within one year following a hip fracture in patients over 60 years old is 2.78, which is a 178% increase in risk compared to the general population. Peter Attia emphasizes that hip fractures are a devastating outcome that should be avoided at any age, but especially in older adults.

title: Fracture Statistics in Older Adults
content: The most frequent fractures in people over 65 years old are proximal femur (hip fractures) and proximal humerus. The median age for hip fractures is 81.1, while the median age for proximal humerus fractures is 66. Falls are a common cause of fractures, highlighting the importance of balance and strength in older adults.

title: Osteopenia and Osteoporosis
content: Osteopenia and osteoporosis represent a continuum of bone mineral density loss relative to healthy bone. Osteopenia is a 10% reduction in bone mineral density, while osteoporosis is a 25% reduction. Diagnosis is based on bone mineral density measurements of the hips and lumbar spine, as these are the most common sites of fractures in older adults.

title: Measuring BMD with DEXA and how to interpret scores
content: DEXA is a low radiation scan that takes 10 minutes and uses two low dose X-rays to differentiate between adipose tissue, bone and lean tissue. Before getting a DEXA scan, confirm that the entity doing this is giving you segmental bone analysis for left hip, right hip, lumbar spine. The price for a full segmental analysis is typically closer to $400. The number you get is not typically reported in grams per centimeter cubed for your BMD because that information is not that helpful. What you really need to know is statistically, where do you rank? This is done via T-score (comparing you to a young, healthy adult) and a Z-score (comparing you to an adult that is your age).

title: Understanding Z-score
content: A Z-Score of 0 means you are right in the middle of the distribution—meaning you have a higher bone mineral density than 50% of people your age, and a lower bone density than 50% of people you age. If your Z-Score is 1.0 it means you are one standard deviation above the mean, which means you have a higher bone density than 82.5% of the people your age and a lower bone density than 17.5% of the population your age. A Z-Score of 2.0 means you are two standard deviations above the mean (higher than 97.5% of the population your age). Of course, this works in reverse so a Z-Score of -2.0 means you have a lower bone density than 97.5% of people your age.

title: T-score
content: Your T-score compares you to a young, healthy adult. So for someone who’s older, the Z-Score is always going to be more favorable than the T-score.

title: Factors that affect BMD
content: Family history, history of smoking, current lifestyle, how active is that person, how much weight-bearing activity are they doing, and being male versus female also factors into it a lot.

title: The effect of estrogen withdrawal on bone density
content: A 42-year-old female patient who is three to five years out from menopause and already has a low Z-Score is a cause for concern due to the effect of estrogen withdrawal on bone density.

title: The importance of muscle and bone density
content: Peter Attia emphasizes the importance of muscle and bone density, stating that no one has ever wished to be less strong or have lower bone density, even at 90 years old.

title: Variability in bone mineral density between sexes and races
content: There are differences in bone mineral density between sexes and races, with women experiencing a significant decrease in BMD after menopause. Non-Hispanic Black individuals tend to have higher BMD than non-Hispanic White and Mexican-American individuals.

title: When to have a bone mineral density scan
content: The standard recommendation for bone mineral density scans is typically 65 for women and 70 for men, but high-risk individuals over the age of 50 may need to be screened earlier. Peter Attia believes that women in their thirties should also be screened and is just as interested in their bone mineral density as other factors.

title: The importance of early bone mineral density screening
content: Peter Attia believes that a low Z-Score in a 35-year-old patient is just as concerning as elevated postprandial glucose and insulin levels, highlighting the importance of early bone mineral density screening.

title: Changes in bone mineral density throughout life
content: Bone mineral density increases significantly during childhood and adolescence, with most of the growth in bone length and size occurring during this time. BMD tends to plateau for women after their twenties and decreases significantly after menopause.

title: Bone Density and Bone Loss
content: Bone density increases up to the age of 30 and then bone loss starts to occur. Women experience more bone loss than men, especially around the onset of menopause. By the age of 65, bone loss slows down for women and increases for men. There is a separate trajectory for women who didn't reach their full genetic potential by the age of 20. However, bone mass can still be improved through hard work before menopause.

title: Age-Related BMD Loss
content: Both men and women experience bone loss in both cortical and trabecular bones. Women lose more BMD in the trabecular/spongy part of the bone, while they are no different than men when it comes to the cortical section of bone.

title: Impact of Estrogen on Bone Health
content: Bone mass increases in the presence of stress. Muscles are attached via tendons to bones, and bones feel the load put on those muscles. Estrogen plays a role in bone health.

title: Estrogen's role in bone health
content: The signaling process to deposit more bone tissue is regulated heavily by estrogen. In the absence of estrogen, that signal gets reduced and that’s effectively why menopause, which is a sudden withdrawal of estrogen, is such a devastating thing for women who don’t have their hormones replaced. Men also lose estrogen as they age, but at a far more gradual rate than women. Adiposity can give men more estrogen. Men lose estrogen primarily from testosterone conversion. Menopause makes women at greater risk for osteopenia and osteoporosis.

title: HRT and bone health
content: HRT is not considered standard of care for postmenopausal bone loss, despite the fact that it reduces fracture risk. The Women’s Health Initiative found that the risk of breast cancer and cardiovascular disease went up with HRT. However, the increase in the risk of breast cancer was virtually nonexistent. Today, we can say with much more clarity that the risk of breast cancer from hormone replacement therapy is virtually nonexistent. The risk of cardiovascular disease has been completely ameliorated by the adoption of topical forms of estradiol, as opposed to oral forms of estradiol. Today, we actually know that HRT reduces the risk of cardiovascular disease in women, and does not increase it. Taking all together, these suggest to Peter that bone health should in fact be a consideration for women as they consider whether or not HRT makes sense for them.

title: Factors determining who may be at higher risk of poor bone health
content: Genetics accounted for up to 50% of bone health. Having either parent that’s had a history of a hip fracture is a huge red flag. We want to look at fractures related to mild or moderate trauma. Female athletes, especially runners where weight is such an important part of the sport, are at risk of poor bone health.

title: Female Athlete Triad
content: When you look at high-end female endurance athletes, we care a lot about poor nutritional state, which can lead to a very low BMI, low body fat percent, and eventually estrogen deficiency. These interrelated conditions of the low bone health, hormone dysfunction, and low BMI are collectively known as the female athlete triad. Low BMI in general, so anything below about 18 or 19.

title: High Exposure to Drugs that Affect Bone Metabolism
content: The other thing we look at is people who have had high exposure to drugs that affect bone metabolism. The most common of these that we see is corticosteroids. It can also be inhaled corticosteroids. Smoking is also an independent risk factor for low BMD.

title: Common Drugs that can Negatively Impact BMD
content: Corticosteroids have to be considered the first and most important one of these drugs you want to be considerate about. They impair the mineralization of bone by favoring bone reabsorption during the early phase. Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and antiepileptic drugs tend to have a similar association, although probably from a different mechanism. One in particular, which is phenytoin, so a super common anti-seizure drug. The mechanism might have more to do with liver inducing an enzyme called cytochrome P450, that leads to increased catabolism of vitamin D.

title: Optimizing Bone Health in Children
content: During the ages of 8 to 20, the most important thing for optimizing bone health is being adequately nourished and being very active, particularly in things that load bones. Running doesn’t have a greater impact on BMD because of a confounder in body weight and BMI. Rucking is a great exercise for BMD. Other sports that involve more power, such as jumping and lifting heavy things, are also recommended. Make sure BMI is not too low, hormone dysfunction is not there, energy availability is there, body fat is not too low, and kids are not smoking.

title: Types of Physical Activity for Bone Health
content: The more force that a muscle is applying to a bone, the more force you are trying to put on the muscle, the better it is for bone health. Resistance training is significantly better at retaining BMD than anything aerobic, and powerlifting is more effective than regular strength training in maintaining BMD in postmenopausal women.

title: Resistance Training and High Force Impact Sports for BMD
content: Resistance training and high force impact sports like football and MMA are associated with the highest BMD values. Low weight bearing, low impact exercises like walking, swimming, and cycling don't seem to do much to improve BMD. Walking with a rucksack, walking uphill, and walking downhill are great exercises to improve BMD. The more the exercise strains the muscles, the better it is for the bones.

title: BMD of Competitive Athletes
content: Competitive athletes have very high BMDs compared to the average man and woman. Even swimmers and resistance training females have excellent BMDs. MMA and football generate the highest BMDs due to the strong forces applied across muscles and transmitted to bones.

title: The Sweet Spot: Resistance Training
content: Resistance training is the sweet spot for increasing BMD. However, all exercises come with risks if not done correctly. Walking, gardening, and golf are not effective exercises for increasing BMD.

title: Weight Loss and BMD
content: Weight loss can negatively impact BMD, especially in the obese and elderly. Resistance training is recommended during weight loss to maintain lean mass and prevent a decrease in BMD.

title: Impact of Nutritional Manipulations and Exercise on Bone Mineral Density
content: When people lose weight purely through nutritional manipulations, they tend to lose bone mineral density. However, when people lose weight in combination with significant exercise, they tend to gain bone mineral density. It's been suggested that the BMD reduction due to weight loss may be caused less by the mechanical loading of bones and more by a change in some of the adipose derived factors like leptin and adiponectin and other hormones that move around when weight loss changes. Loading the muscles and therefore transmitting that load to bones can offset some of that. Exercise is the single most important tool we have anyway, and it should be employed as an important part of a weight loss strategy if this is just one of the other bonuses that comes with it, which is an ability to minimize the BMD loss that is almost inevitable with weight loss.

title: Essential Nutrients for Optimizing Bone Deposition
content: The big three micronutrients that matter for optimizing bone deposition are calcium, vitamin D (D3 specifically), and magnesium. Calcium, about 1000 to 1200 milligrams daily, vitamin D, 800 to 1000 IU daily, and magnesium, 300 to 500 milligrams daily, can be supplemented if you can’t get this sufficiently in food or through sunlight in the case of vitamin D. Calcium carbonate and calcium citrate are reasonable options for supplementing calcium. On the magnesium side, it really depends on what your gut can tolerate. Magnesium citrate, glycinate, and oxide are fantastic if you’re looking for a little speed up of the bowel. If you aren’t, you want magnesium carbonate. Peter likes to mix them up by supplementing with mag carbonate in the mornings, mag oxide at night, and also use a bit of mag glycinate with L-threonate as well. He’s routinely hitting about a gram of magnesium supplementally. It’s pretty hard to get 500 grams predictably of absorbed magnesium every single day, and that’s a real minimum — a gram is really where you want to be. Calcium’s a bit easier to get if you consume dairy, but a lot of plant-based people aren’t going to eat dairy so they have to look to other things.

title: Pharmaceutical drugs prescribed for those with low BMD
content: Drugs are typically last line of defense (and Peter would will refer people out of his practice for this as he’s not enough of an expert). There’s three big classes: 1 – Bisphosphonates – this is the main class of drug for this purpose. 2 – monoclonal antibodies. 3 – synthetic parathyroid hormone. Bisphosphonates increase BMD by about four to 6% in the critical areas that matter, the femoral, neck, the hip, the lumbar spine, and they reduce the risk of fractures. The other two classes of drugs, monoclonal antibodies and synthetic parathyroid hormone, also show efficacy.

title: Impact of extreme sedentary periods on bone health
content: Disuse osteopenia occurs when bones are chronically unloaded, leading to high bone resorption and low bone formation. This can be seen in extreme cases such as astronauts returning from space. For most people, this is relevant during bedrest due to injuries or pregnancy. Bone loss due to disuse osteopenia is incremental and progressive, occurring more rapidly in trabecular bone than in cortical bone. To combat this, any form of PT that can actively load muscles is recommended, including cyclic blood flow restriction training (BFR).

title: Bisphosphonate study on immobilized mice
content: A study on immobilized mice found that bisphosphonate treatment inhibited osteoclastic bone resorption and prevented bone loss due to immobility. The treated mice showed no significant difference in bone health compared to control mice. While it is unclear if this will be true in humans, this type of research is important for combating immobility, especially in aging populations.
